Author: wrdg
Content:
Scripting in dayz is no where similar to arma‚Äôs SQF, there‚Äôs not really your core documented global methods that you have available in SQF. DayZ is Enforce script, it shares similar syntax with C# and C a bit of C. It‚Äôs more OOP, and you‚Äôre going to be deal with inheritance. If you‚Äôre familiar with any modern production programming language, you‚Äôll at least have basic understanding of what you want to do just mainly syntax is the hurdle. 

There‚Äôs a bit of starter documentation on BI‚Äôs wiki to get you started.

Script Syntax
https://community.bistudio.com/wiki/DayZ:Enforce_Script_Syntax

Mod Structure (for packing and deploying)
https://community.bistudio.com/wiki/DayZ:Modding_Structure

Workbench Setup and Debugging
https://community.bistudio.com/wiki/DayZ:Workbench_Script_Debugging

And here‚Äôs some official hare bone samples
https://github.com/BohemiaInteractive/DayZ-Samples

Most of your time scripting is going to be ‚Äúreverse engineering‚Äù the scripts, mainly finding what you want to mod, the systems connected and sample syntax and logic within the vanilla scripts. A good majority here use Mikero‚Äôs tools, DayZ2P is a good start to get things unpacked, you‚Äôd want to download the DayZ tools first and setup a P: drive to dedicate your projects and vanilla source to.

Author: .expunged
Content: Yeah SQF is nowhere near Enforce and I'm mostly familiar with other OOP language. To find out methods and whatnot I'll have to go into the game's own scripts or others'? I've been spoiled with the Arma Community Wiki lol

Author: wrdg
Content: Correct, for BI to create a wiki like how it is with SQF would take an immense amount of time as they'd have to create their own documentation parser and go back over everything. There's not really a decent entry point to get started. I'd suggest getting a code editor that can do mass searches, like VS Code or Sublime (Ctrl + Shift + F), which will search in an entire directory and sub directories for the text you're wanting to find. DayZ isn't full Enfusion either, and you'll find some similarities with arma for the config side of things (CfgVehicles, Units, etc).

Author: wrdg
Content: Also if you're wanting to understand someone else's idea and logic, not everyone code is perfect, so make sure you instantiate a good standard and naming convention if you decide to decompile and look at other people's mods and scripts

Author: wrdg
Content: If you're blinding decompiling then copying and pasting people scripts from their mods like the workshop is StackOverflow.com, you're going to have a hard time learning and understanding what you're doing and why.
